title: Scale Armor
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I wanted to make some accessories for a costume and I got the Idea to make a scale armor shoulder piece. I did some research and found, that the basic principle of a scale armor is quite simple.
Print, paint, and tie together, that's it.

Printer:

Fabbster G

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

No

Infill:

100%

The .stl file contains 5 variations of the scales. I printed 5 each for the first prototype. I sanded the scales down a little and gave them a silver base paint. Then I randomly sprayed a brown, rutsy coat of paint.
In later Versions I will give the scales an Acetone dip and add some more organic weathering to the individual scales.
To hold it all together I used 2-3mm leather bands. See Images for details. You can vary the rigidity of the armor by loosening or tightening the bands.

title: Brio style wooden track stackable bridge support

description.text:
My Son had very few track supports for his Brio style wooden track, so I decided to print him a few more. They are based on the existing wooden supports he has, and are stackable. They were designed in Sketchup, simply because it was easy to do there, however I had a lot of issues getting a manifold stl so it needed running through an stl fixer. I think I'll go back to OpenSCAD for the next design.
At the moment they use quite a lot of filament. I may look into creating a thinner one, however some depth is required to support the track join.

These were printed on a Prusa i3 with a .4mm nozzle and in PLA. Layer height at .3mm with 3 perimeters and 30% infill. Perhaps it may be sensible to drop down the perimeters and infill to save on filament, although this is untested.

description.text:
I have a Fiamma Aqua 8 water pump, which lost lots of its pumping capacity.
Turns out the three acryllic(?) "pistons" inside were cracked and broken to pieces.
Replacements are available at Fiamma, but not these pistons as a set, you get almost half a pump when you order the part number. It costs almost 50 euros!

I printed these pistons in ABS with a 0.2mm layer height, 35% infill and 3 outline perimeters as well as 3 top and bottom layers.

author: Mchartier2011

description.text:
I wasn't happy with the options for mounting my Mobius Action Cam to my car windscreen for DVR use. Most were too bulky, or hung down too far, and i was after a mount which made it more discrete. I decided to disassemble one of the screen mounts I had and design an adaptor to do the job. I've included a few different angles, but have only tested 10 degrees which I found to be perfect in my Audi A3. I would assume it would be a good angle for most similar size cars.

I've included the OpenSCAD file if you wish to make modifications.

I would recommend using ABS or other filament which is resistant to heat. My initial print was in PLA, and the heat in the car was enough to warp the plastic and allow to camera to move about. The replacement ABS part remained in shape.
A phone

print_settings.Notes:: Printed using PETG. ABS should work too. PLA is probably too stiff. Use 100% infill in order to make a strong part that supports tension well.

remixed_from.title: Flexing battery holders with integrated spring

title: Flexing 18650 battery bracket with integrated spring

description.text:
This is a cut-off and slightly modified version of the original design by enif. I designed this for building battery packs out of 18650 cells, where the cells are most efficiently stacked in a staggered pattern.
I have not actually built a pack out of these yet, since I've just made my first functioning prints.
I'm printing in PETG, but ABS should also work. PLA may be too stiff. Use 100% infill.
Batteries should be inserted near the spring where the thing is most flexible, and then pushed towards the flat side.
Unfortunately I don't know enough about OpenSCAD to make this parametric like the original.

title: Spectrograph / Spectroscope (LOWSPEC)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A spectrograph lets you analyse light. Attaching it to a telescope enables you to discover all sorts of things about the stars. In fact, almost all we know about the universe has been obtained through spectroscopy!
This field of science is becoming more and more popular amongst amateur astronomers. A commercial spectrograph however will set you back € 2000 or more!
That’s why I decided to build one with a 3D printer. Of course, you’ll have to buy the optical components (slit, lenses, mirrors and grating) . But that will ‘only’ cost you about € 500. Which is a huge difference compared with a commercial spectrograph. This spectrograph is designed for telecopes which are f/8 or slower.

I've included the source file so you will be able to make some adjustments for you own needs.

I do not have in-depth knowledge of optics. So if you can improve this design, please let me know. Even better, share it with the rest of the world!

Best regards,
Paul Gerlach

Printer:

Felix Pro 2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

100-200 micron

Infill:

50-80%

Notes:

The main body can be printed at 200-250 micron (infill >= 50%).
Print smaller part a 100 micron with 80% infill.
Some parts require support.

The LOWSPEC has been designed to accept different slit modules. The OVIO slit module contains the OVIO slit plate with 12 different slits to choose from (10, 10, 30, 40, 50, 70, 100, 150, 200, 300, 500 and 700 micron). They can be rotated into position making the instrument more suitable for different telescopes. The ALPY slit module contains a ALPY photometric slit with a slit of 23/200 micron.

The OVIO slit plate can be purchased here:
https://en.ovio-optics.com/jetons-fentes-radiales-pr-193206.html

The ALPY photometric slit:
https://www.shelyak.com/produit.php?id_produit=107&id_rubrique=17

Step 1

Print the main body at 200 micron with >=50% infill. Use support (max overhang 60 degrees).
Remove support after printing.
Check that the two threads fit the main body before you glue them in place using two component Epoxy glue.

Step 2A

You can use a 3/8" nut so you can eventually attach the instrument to a photo tripod. Glue the plug in place.

Step 2B

Screw in the threaded M4 insert.

Step 3

Use a M4 threading tool to thread the four locations indicated.
Next screw Allen Grub Screws (M4) into these threaded holes.

Step 4A

Insert the round coupling nut M5 x 25mm (mine had a diameter of 7.9mm) into the center hole of the focus slider. It should be a tight fit and you may have to resort to some brute force...

Step 4B

Push the M3 nuts into the slots (two in both rail holders).
Cut two pieces of aluminum pipe (length 55mm, diameter 6mm) and slide them into the two other holes of the focus slider. Make sure that they can slide smoothly.

Step 4C

Slide one coilspring over one of the the aluminum tubes. Assemble this part by sliding both rail holders over the tube ends.

Step 4D

Make sure the whole focus part fits in the designated slots underneath the main body. If it does not then make sure that both sliding tubes are pressed far enough into the rail holders.
Still no fit? Than you’ll have to shorten both sliding tubes a bit.

Step 4E

Screw it in place with four M3 cylinder screws.
Check that the focus slider can travel the whole length!

Step 4F

Take a M5 x 80mm cylinder screw and screw it all the way in.

Step 4G

Place a M5 washer over the cylinder screw and screw on the Knurled nut. Make sure not to screw it to tight against the washer.
Finally screw the M5 locking nut tight against the knurled nut with a spanner while holding the M5x80mm cylinder screw in place with a screw driver.
Test the focus-unit by turning the knurled nut. It should turn relatively smoothly.
If the focuser if funcioning fine place the cover as shown below.

Step 5A

Press the mirror into the main mirror holder. Wear gloves so you will not damage the mirror!
Also insert a M3 nut in the slot on the backside of the mirror holder.

Step 5B

Make sure the Allen Grub Screws do not protrude before placing the mirror holder.

Step 5C

Place the mirror holder and secure it with a M3x10mm Philips screw. Take care not to over tighten the screw. The three Allen Grub Screws will be used later to change the tilt of the mirror.

Step 6

Cut a aluminum pipe (dia. 6mm) to length (16mm) and secure it in place with some glue into the hole of the focus slider.

Step 7A

Use a M4 threading tool for the small hole and screw in a 6mm Allen Grub Screw.
Press the camera lens into the holder (should be a tight fit). Be aware of the correct orientation of the lens.

Step 7B

Slide the camera lens holder over the protruding piece of aluminum pipe and tighten the Grub Screw. Make sure the biggest bulging side is facing as illustrated.

Step 8A

Press the collimator lens into its holder. Wear gloves to protect the surface of the lens. Note the position of the parts. Insert a M3 nut all the way into its slot.

Step 8B

Place the collimator holder in the slot at the bottom of the main body. Take note of the orientation.

Step 8C

Use a M3x12mm philips cylinder screw to keep the collimator in place.
By loosening this screw a bit you are able to slide the collimator back and forth.

Step 9A

Use a 4M wire tap to tap the two holes on top of the rotary section of the grating holder.
Screw in two M4x6mm Allen Grub Screws.
Carefully slide in the reflective grating. Take great care not to touch the surface of the grating as it can easily be damaged!
Also, notice the arrow that is drawn on one of the sides of the grating (the 'blaze direction'). It should be pointing in the direction as is indicated in the illustration above.
Gently tighten the two Allen Grub Screws so that they hold the grating in place. Be careful! Over tightening them could break the glass grating!

Step 9B

Place the whole rotary section onto the base plate and put the cap on top.
Check that the rotary section can move freely. If needed you can glue the cap to the base.

Step 9C

Insert two M3x12mm Cylinder Philips screws and install the spring.
Take care not to damage the grating!

Step 9D

Insert two M3 nuts into the indicated positions above.

Step 9E

Gently screw the grating holder in position. Again, take great care not to damage the surface of the grating. To access the screw under the coil spring you may need to push it aside a bit with you screwdriver. Take care not to touch the grating!. The other screw can be accessed by rotating the grating.

OVIO slit module

This part discribes the assembly of the OVIO slit adapter.
If you have chosen the ALPY slit configuration, please skip this part.

Step 10A - OVIO

Use a thread tap to tap the holes that are pointed out in the illustration above.

Step 10B - OVIO

The OVIO slit module uses some additional hardware:

  • a steel ball (diameter 5 mm)
  • half piece of a ball pen spring
  • M6x6 mm Allen grub screw

Insert the ball and the spring into the hole and screw in the M6x6 grub screw. With this screw you can adjust the force that the spring exerts on the steel ball.

Step 10C - OVIO

Keep the OVIO slit plate as clean as possible. Preferably wear gloves.

Place the disc into the holder. Take note of the orientation! Make sure that slit number 1 is above the hole in the red circle. Also make sure the disc in 'upside down' so the numbers are in mirror image.

Step 10D - OVIO

Screw in the locking ring (use the 'locking tool'). Make sure the OVIO slit plate is kept in place by holding it down while you tighten it. Take your time.
Check the alignment of the slit and adjust the slit plate if necessary.

Step 10E - OVIO

Attach the locking plate with three M3x10mm Philps screws.
Check that the ring can rotate and that it clicks into position.

Step 10F - OVIO

Press the guide mirror into the socket of the guide mirror holder. Push the guide mirror holder in it's socket. Make sure it's pushed in all the way.
The OVIO slit module is now complete.

This part describes the assembly of the ALPY slit module.
If you’ve chosen the OVIO slit module, you can skip this part and move to step 11A

Step 10A - ALPY

Tap M4 thread and place the ALPY slit. Secure it with a M4x6mm crub screw. Make sure the orientation of the slit is correct.

Step 10B - ALPY

insert the guide mirror and place the guide mirror holder into it's position.
The ALPY slit module is now complete.

Step 11A

Insert the autoguide lens into it's holder (15_holder_guide_lens). Make sure that the more curved surface is facing the guide mirror...

Step 11B

...and push this into the socket at the back of the autoguide port.
Make sure it's firmly in place. If in doubt use some glue to keep it in place.

Step 12

Place the micrometer and secure it with the Allen Grub Screw.
The micrometer used has a mounting diameter of 9.5mm and a travel of 1-13mm.

Step 13A

Insert the five M4 locking nuts.

Step 13B

Slide the slit module into it's slot and place the appropriate lid.
Secure it with five hexagon socket head cap screws (M4 x60mm).
Also screw in the knurled Screw (M4 x 20mm).

The assembly is now complete!

comments.text: hey, what are the supported wavelenghts in the finished product. just visible and UV or could it go IR?
comments.author: Vipitis

comments.text:
Well it's was constructed for the optical spectrum (400 - 700 nm). These are the specifications of the used lenses. Beyond 700 nm (or 7000 Angstrom) is possible. At the short wavelength part (beyond 380 nm) there is some blurring. Probably because these achromatic lenses were not designed for that particular part of the spectrum.
Also PLA seams to be transparent in the infrared part of the spectrum. So if you were to use PLA for this project, then I would suggest to cover the device in some aluminum foil.
I used ASA and have not experienced Infrared transparency with this material.
comments.author: Vipitis

comments.text: Hi Paul, thanks for the "congrates", but, all credit goes to you for designing this in the 1st place and then putting it out there for guys like me to copy and build. You did all the clever thinking. On the plastic, no idea, my mate printed for me. He's preference I suppose. He has some or other fancy hi-tech printer and has a hobbyist model printing setup. If I see a problem, I will paint black inside. Should be okay though as all is dark outside and unit is sealed. Thanks for the tip on the 100mm lens for back focus. Yes, was planning outside on the solar spectra this morning and saw the back focus issue. Of course, no problem for the ZWO, but of course spectrum is too large for the chip and one has to “page” through it. I’m off to the ATM class and will see if I can scratch out a 100mm lens from one of the boxes of scrap. On the guide mirror, still work in progress. Going to sort this out when the proper slit arrives. Thanks though for the tip – great idea. Looking forward to showing the guys at telescope class.

comments.author: Percymj

comments.text:
The LOWSPEC with the 300 l/mm grating has a higher resolution (R~800-900) than the ALPY.
Grating and lens combo has been chosen so that 4000 to 7000 Angstroms are covered on a ATIK314L CCD.
A 600l/mm grating will double the resolution but also half the spectral coverage.

blitzu mount v3 w/o GoPro (req)
Metal Corner

This part is meant to:
  • connect a bowden setup to a wade's type extruder driver
  • mount the whole thing (extruder driver + bowden cable) on the top threaded rods of a reprap

This is very messy for now! (cleanup in progress)
  • The bowdenfit* params need to be adapted to the size of the hole at the base of your wade's extuder
  • Set the threaded_rod_distance to the distance between your top threaded rods (center to center)
  • mount_hole_dist needs to be sufficiently big to make sure the biggest gear on your extruder won't hit the lateral threaded rod of your reprap
    • -The defaults in the scad , and the stl file, are working 'as is' for a emaker-huxley type reprap, with 3mm filament bowden setup and a hinged wade's extruder with j-head mount hole

description.text: The DJI Inspire 2 Battery Ejector / Hot Swap Tool allows the user to eject the batteries from the DJI Inspire 2 drone individually. User will be able to “hot swap” the batteries meaning they can swap a depleted battery for a charged one without having to turn off the drone. remixed_from.title: Idler pulley with tooth for Anet a2 (a6,a8)

title: Anet A8 Toothed Idler Pulley for 8mm bearings
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: So the original design was a problem for me because the original bearings had a skirt sticking out that made the width about 2.5mm wider than original width. I did get it to fit into the holder, but the fit was very tight and the pulley had way too much drag and bed was hard to move. I did not have any 10mm bearings, but I did have a bunch of 8mm bearings from old broken brushless motors, and these are fairly cheap and common for anyone that's into RC or drones. So I made a slight modification to the original to allow for using 8mm bearings and for me this worked out perfectly. The original design would be better if you have a pair of 10mm bearings available, but if you have some old brushless motors or order a bunch of 8mm bearings this will work for you

title: Felfil Evo - Basic Kit - DIY Upgrade

description.text:
This is the DIY upgrade for the Felfil Evo Basic Kit.

It's free available for everyone, you can build it if you want to have fun creating a cheap and easy to use filament extruder.

Please remember that, in order to properly extrude, you will need to buy the Felfil Evo Basic Kit -> https://goo.gl/CMhQNp

Here you can find the vectorial file (.dxf) that you can use for your lasercutter.
In this case we chose an 8mm thickness wood.

What you further need in order to extrude is easily findable on some common ecommerce:

  • PID with SSR (solid state relay) and thermocouple
  • Ammeter
  • General switch
  • RPM controller for engine
  • 200W, 12V power supply

Deeper instructions are available on GitHub:
http://bit.ly/GitHubFelfil

Feel free to study this project, remix it, or contact use in case you need some informations.

comments.text: Some notes from my experience while launching the basic kit:
comments.author: glassy

comments.text:
Thanks for your great job Glassy!
It will be super-useful for all the other Felfil Evo Basic Kit owners. You are right, PIN 4 in Arduino do not work in PWM so in this guide ( https://github.com/CollettivoCocomeri/Felfil-Evo/blob/master/FEBK%20-%20Basic%20Kit/FEBK%20Complete%20by%20CC/Felfil-Basic%20Kit%20Electronics.pdf ) we already connected the motor to PWM PIN3. Can I ask you where you find the Motor-PIN4 connection in order to correct it?
All the best
Ale from Felfil

comments.text: Also have just made a thing https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2460758 for cooling the extruder motor. Apparently it helps to keep the motor current stabile during long working time when it is cooled. Please feel free to use/mention it in your docs if you see reasonable.

title: Lock plate for vintage camper refrigerator

description.text: The door on our old camper fridge wouldn't latch shut. It turn out the lower plate of the simple latch mechanism had become worn over the years and wasn't holding the latch in place. A few quick measurements and 10 minutes later I had a solution.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.35

Infill:

no

Notes:

Because of the irregular shape, I needed supports, I set the interface layer spacing to 1mm in Slic3r Prusa Edition and they came off no problem.

Only other tricky part was the hollow tube, which wasn't slicing properly until I checked off "detect thin walls".

Printed in 10 minutes and fits like a charm.

I used PLA, but I think nylon would provide a better result.

remixed_from.author: lkiesow
remixed_from.title: Renault clio GT trunk rail tip (right)

title: Renault Clio touring 2009 trunk rail tip

description.text:
UPDATE:
DO NOT PRINT IN PLA (unless you live in a Nordic country)! First hot day it took (35ºC), both ends got totally twisted and curled... now they are useless!!!

The original didn't quite fit without some persuasion so I've tweaked it. There were differences between Clio version and year on the original files (GT 2008 to Touring 2009), though I'm not sure these were relevant.

These worked nicely in a Clio Touring 2009.

There are no major differences only small tweaks - part got about 1mm longer and 0.5mm wider and the hook got rounded and slimmer (not yet perfectly I may add).

Printed in PLA at 50% infill, 0.2 resolution and it is holding so far but I guess something less temperature sensitive (ABS) would be better and higher resolution would provide a more durable part.

Unfortunately I don't have any experience or knowledge on 3D modeling so I've used Windows 3d Builder to remix this and that is a very limited app for the purpose (though it got the job done).

comments.author: yh125d

comments.text: @yh125d this one is for 623ZZ
comments.author: yh125d

comments.text:
Amusing, there are still people using this old trick in this age of polymer and linear ball bearings which are far superior in any sense ?
Even the cheap chinese LM with the proper hardened rod (not the crap SS metrinch rods usually supplied) are far better, smaller, even cheaper !
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text:
@MKSA
You wrote similar things in the comment section of the original part. Honestly, I would be very interested in the reasons why linear ball bearings are better in your opinion. My linear bearings went to hell after 6 months, they began to stutter and I even had layer shifting because of them beginning to roll so badly. Yes, it might have been just dirt inside, but I cleaned them as much as I could and it didn't change a thing. It was obvious that the balls simply didn't roll smooth anymore and I couldn't figure out why. My hardened rods where fine, so that could not have been the reason...
comments.author: MKSA

comments.text: Because they are not smart at all. Clumsy, heavy, a very old attempt at linear bearing using regular bearings inspired by the ones using grooved or rubber rollers. Regular bearings are unfit for the job. The 3D community, in fact most people without a clue in mechanic keep reinventing outdated or failed designs.

comments.text: Many thanks for your attempt to explain a bit further and your fast answer,  much apprecitated.

title: Chevy Volt (2017) Phone Mount Xiaomi Mi5

description.text:
**Work in progress, will upload pictures later.

This is a phone mount for the 2017 Chevrolet volt plug in EV. It's printed in two parts and can be glued with any suitable phone holder; I've included one for my phone, the Xiaomi Mi5.

It's mounted on the driver side accessories bay column. It's roughly hand drawn, so the fit is not perfect around the column. The fit for the phone, and USB-C cable, is perfect (use the included Xiaomi USB-C cable.

A great accessory for using android auto, phone slides right in. M3 hardware may need to be pressed in, depending on printer tolerances.

Highly recommend printing in ABS or PETG, something with a little flex and won't warp too easily on a hot summer day.

Required:

  • 2x M3 hex nut
  • 2x M3x12 screw
  • Xiaomi USB-C cable
  • Xiaomi Mi5
  • screwdriver

Assembly is self explanatory, see pictures. Tighten down the screws to your liking. Slide USB-C cable in. Enjoy Android auto.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

15

Notes:

The fit isn't perfect so use a more flexible filament like ABS or PETG and tighten down the nuts a little bit. PLA will warp in a hot car.

Use a tiny bit of support on bed only for the USB-C insert.

description.text:
DJI Spark RC Stick Guard

Description

I had issues with other designs of the stick guards I found. They were a bit fiddly getting them on and off and I think they would start to wear the rubber down on the sticks, so I decided to do my own design to reduce the wear and tear on the rubber on the sticks.

Suggest supports so the fillets where the sticks enters and the Text gets some support.

Constructive Feedback welcome as I knocked up this design in 20 minutes so it may not be the final version.

I will work on the Mavic version one as well due to similar issues with wear and tear if this one gets good feedback.

Updates

9/9/2017: Added a V3.
This has a lower profile as the new case I got for the spark would not accept the height of the vertical support of the V2.

title: Orange Pi Zero Box wood CNC lasercut

description.text:
This is my OrangePi Zero wood box used for SqueezeLite (hole for 3.5mm audio jack).

If you want to use it for another application, feel free to remix (parametric SCAD file provided)

  • Make :
    I did this box with an MPCNC using 3mm plywood with a 1.5mm tool successfully

  • Build :
    I glued top pieces, the bottom one slides to close the box.
    (In my case, friction keep it close)
    There is 2 holes on bottom to put 2 screws. Those will go trough orangepi holes.
    Be carefull to use less than 3mm diameter screws (outer diameter).
    In my case, I remove the serial port pins to place audio jack.

EDIT v1.1 : Hole added on the back for status leds and holes on top and longsides for cooling
EDIT v1.1b : Added holes on bottom too
EDIT v1.1c : move holes on longsides to improve build

remixed_from.author: Team_UnLimbited
remixed_from.title: The UnLimbited Arm v2.1 - Alfie Edition

description.text:
!!--WORK IN PROGRESS--!!

!!--GIVE US FEEDBACK SO WE CAN MAKE IT BETTER--!!

The prosthetic limb featured herein was created by "Team Unlimited." They are the inspiration for our project and our modifications are based on their design. Learn more about Team Unlimited at www.teamunlimbited.org

The Unlimbited Arm (Remix) - Edmund Edition arm is an open source, 3D printed prosthetic arm that uses a pull-to-activate gripping system. By removing wrist or elbow grip activation, this hand doesn't require constant strain or bending to keep a solid grip. Instead, the user pulls a Velcro tab and locks it in place. Once locked, the grip of the hand is both strong enough to ride a bike and dexterous enough to use a pencil.

For complete assembly guide, see Instructables.

This design is based on the UnLimbited Arm v2.1 - Alfie Edition.

Improvements

  • Added groove to the palm to fit handlebar
  • Fused the first knuckle on fingers for improved grip and rigidity
  • Added small grooves and inserts for elastic bands to support pen/pencil use
  • Replaced wrist activation with pull and lock Velcro tab
  • Added forearm support

Project Story
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=u9djaQ84ruY

description.text: Oye! Oye! Zheng3 3D Printing Kickstarter #4 is due to launch in Spring 2016! Join the Horde to be notified when we launch and-- AND! receive a free 3D model not available anywhere else! We now return you to your regular model description.

"Snoozing on his throne, the last sound Lord Aethelred heard was a flaming cask of night soil splintering the Great Hall's rafters." --Qie Zi, The Art of Seej The Penny Mortar will loft a U.S. penny over the sofa with contemptuous ease. The zip file contains all pieces broken out so that international Thingiversians can scale the nock for their local coinage.

Construction requires a pair of elastic bands. See the Zheng3 Penny Ballista for detailed instructions on rigging the bands through the posts and nock. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:23464 Flagrant stagecraft alert: there's a piece of hookup wire holding the nock in firing position. Seej is a tabletop wargame based around 3D printing. Check out http://s33j.net for rules and more information. At a minimum, you'll need the Seej starter set: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:24013 You can also search Thingiverse for Things with the seej tag. Be sure to check Zheng3.com for updates. If Twitter's more your thing then follow Zheng3 at http://twitter.com/Zheng3_Jim

author: discovercamp110

description.text:
Here you go with another piece of impossible seeming geometrical object. This time, I´ve made the (yet impossible but easily openable) Dovetail Box for you!
When looking at it fot the first time, almost everyone might classify opening the box as an impossible action. But you don´t even have to change your view towards it for 180 degrees - even 45 degrees are actually enough. That´s simply because the two inserted parts can be easily taken out of each other by sliding them 45 degrees diagonally based on the side edge. And surprise - you´ve opened it!

I´ve added a bottom part which is the base of every Dovetail box. From there on, you can go up by systematically adding more and more pieces. There are straight parts (where the object bejond it has the same diagonal orientation as the object above it, like the orange one) and twisted ones (where it is the other way round, like the blue one).
There it might be a bit complicated now: If you have used one twisted part, you have to use the "rotated" files for all following parts until you use another twisted one (which also still has to be a rotated one, in order to make them fit perfectly into each other.
Mathematically spoken, for all the nerds among you - The twisting level "t" of every box starts with 0 and gets increased by one with every twisted part that gets put onto the box. If "t" is an equal number, you have to use the normal parts, if "t" is odd, you have to use the rotated ones.

So, have fun with this box, and please let me know if there is any space for improvement. I´m looking forward to see your boxes here!

title: Spriya Anet A8 Fan Duct with upgraded connector

description.text: I didn't like having my fan at an angle because the duct had to go between the fan and the extruder, however the other common duct mount didn't seem secure so I combined the two most common fan duct mounts into one. Print with the same settings as the original model. The second model is updated to have a tighter fit.

Supports:

Yes

Notes:

Support overhang angle should be 80° set to everywhere rather than build plate only to prevent filling the entire duct with support.

comments.text: Dear Chrispage1,
comments.author: RyaReddy

comments.text: The bottom tip of my nozzle is about 25 mm from the bottom of my extruder carriage. When you install the heat break/barrel make sure you put the nut as far down the barrel as possible and then screw in your barrel to align your heater block to the appropriate orientation, then tighten the nut to the bottom of the carriage. This will let you get your extruder as high as it can be and will also make loading filament much easier because the top end of the barrel will be closer to the extruder teeth and guide wheel.
comments.author: RyaReddy

comments.text: Thanks, great build and connects really well! Oh the irony that my build almost got ruined because the stock fan fell off part way through...

author: KAHN3R

description.text:
**Work in progress, picture uploads to come.

This is a 3D printed fume extractor for a ZALMAN CNPS10X OPTIMA 120mm CPU fan I had lying around. May fit similar CPU fans.

Required:

  • 120mm CPU fan (ZALMAN CNPS10X OPTIMA 120mm)
  • Carbon filter (Carbon Filter, ESD, Activated, 5pk for Hakko/Xytronic/Aoyue Smoke Absorber)
  • 12VDC power supply/wall wart (try ebay, AC 100-240V DC 12v 1A 1000mA)
  • 2x 2.54 pin header
  • AC wire plug with switch (from an old lamp)
  • Cable ties or twist ties
    [OPTIONAL LAMP]
  • LED driver (try ebay, 3W LED driver AC 85~265V 700mA output 3v - 6v)
  • LED (Nichia 219B 4500k high-CRI on 14mm all copper MCPCB star)
  • Heatsink aluminum 38mm x 17mm x 11.5mm
  • Aluminum foil
  • double sided sticky tape
  • Glue, could be CA/superglue

This might not be super useful to you since it's modeled for some specific spare parts I had lying around.
Assembly is fairly straight forward, take a look at the pictures.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 5

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

.25

Infill:

15

Notes:

Print in the orientation pictured, must use some supports as shown.
Watch your print tolerances for the CPU fan header insert! You may have to resize a tiny bit.

description.text:
Contacteur triple compatible Feller EDIZIO DUE. La pièce est fixée sur l'étrier métallique comme un interrupteur officiel de la marque, avec 2 petites vis de 1.5-2cm. Agrandir les trous de la pièce à la perceuse en fonction des vis. La plaque frontale s'insère dans le support EDIZIO DUE et est fixée par une petite vis (1.2cm)
Le support des microswitch est prévu pour le modèle visible dans la dernière image (V-15-1C25). Si il y a un bras, comme sur la photo, il faut l'enlever.
Les switch sont reliés à un système de domotique à base d'arduino qui contrôle la lumière et les stores.
J'ai mis une license non commerciale pour éviter les problèmes avec la marque Feller
Le microswitch se trouve facilement chez boxtec.ch et les sites de vente chinois.

author: discovercamp110

title: CoffeeCam: a Shutter for Large Format Pinhole Can Cameras

description.text:
Making a pinhole camera from a can or an oatmeal box is a traditional exercise in beginning photography (see links below). Usually, the cameras produced are perfectly workable, but festooned with abundant gaffer's tape, and use a cumbersome flap of tape as a rudimentary shutter.
This is a shutter and pinhole clamp designed to be fastened onto a small coffee can (espresso-sized) or similar. Used with sheet film or photographic paper, this kind of pinhole camera needs to be loaded with fresh film or paper (in the dark!) for every exposure
Additionally, the shutter assembly can be 3D printed to mount on a flat surface, like a cigar box, OR on the lid of the can for a classic anamorphic pinhole camera. Better yet, put two shutters on your container for some versatility!
Include is a script to generate tripod mounts for both flat and curved sides. As with the shutter assy, change the diameter parameter to fit your can. The TeaCam only needs one radiused mount, and is intended for anamorphic photography exclusively.
.
The OpenSCAD script 'coffeecam.scad' is easy to modify for your chosen cylindrical container or flat-sided boxes.
The OpenSCAD script 'coffeecam_tripod.scad' renders a pair of tripod mounts, one flat and one radiused for your can's diameter.
[Jana_Obscura] is a local photographer who has been testing my camera designs. Here's her latest shoot with the CoffeeCam
Here's more from [EspressoBuzz], another local pinhole photographer.
Both [Jana_Obscura] and [EspressoBuzz] have acted as proofing editors on the P6*6 user manual as well.
======== Addenda ========
Added TeaCam STLs and .scad files for smaller diameter tea tins (~66mm), allowing for clearance of shutter blade and bottom rim, and greater contact area for bonding tripod mount. Republic Of Tea tins have a nice, air-tight snap fit lid and ample room for 4X5 film/paper.
========= LYNX =========
Making Oatmeal Box Pinhole Cameras
Kodak: Making a pinhole camera
PinholeDesigner (windows)
Drill Your Own Precision Pinhole Apertures

print_settings.Printer:: Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

description.text:
I own a 2005 Ford Freestar (3 button) and the key fob broke at the key ring area. I didn't have much luck with the snap together models already available here so, I made my own screw together design. I did find a similar design from 2012 but this one was made mostly from scratch/sketch. I can verify the guts from both the 3 and 4 button key fobs fit ok.

You'll need two m2 x 8mm screws to assemble.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.3mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed at .3mm layer height in PETG @240c / 100c bed. Printed with one outer shell (since 100% infill anyway). I suppose you could use supports for the recessed holes in the top half of the case but I didn't need to.

Designed in Fusion 360, sliced in S3D.

print_settings.Notes:: I use the CraftWare 1.14 beta slicer with good results using the medium resolution auto slice feature, but there is nothing critical about these parts so most any slicer and settings you have found successful should work as well.  I also use Tianse PLA filament, which is the lowest cost filament I have found, with very good results.

description.text:
A rotary tool is practically essential in any model based hobby. There are many top quality units such as Dremel on the market, but for occasional use, the Drill Master 80 piece kit from Harbor Freight, that is frequently on sale for $7, is mostly adequate. It does, however, lack speed control and a organizer for the accessories, so I decided to make my own. I also designed a holder that could be secured to the work bench with screws or “C” clamps to firmly hold the unit in a fixed position. In my initial design I used a tie wrap to secure the unit in the holder, but modified the design to use a sliding member to clamp on the tapered body. I left the tie wrap feature so you can use either one.

The accessory holder has compartments to hold the 3 containers that come with the kit and 25 holes to stow the various tools. The speed control is based upon components (see pictures) I purchased from AliExpress for less than $4. The connectors snap into the housing and are retained by the bottom, which is secured to the main enclosure by 4 #2 x 3/8” sheet metal screws. All the connections are screw type (no soldering required) and the motor and power supply units connect with the OE connectors.

Printer:

Anet A6

auto

I use the CraftWare 1.14 beta slicer with good results using the medium resolution auto slice feature, but there is nothing critical about these parts so most any slicer and settings you have found successful should work as well. I also use Tianse PLA filament, which is the lowest cost filament I have found, with very good results.

title: Spill proof acid brush oil container for lathe or mill

description.text:
I got the idea for this from MrPete222 on youtube who does machine shop class videos. His version required drilling, cutting and soldering, which I could do, but hey I have a 3D printer or 4.

Here is a link to the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=HOAK4-Kd7QA .

The container is used to put an acid brush (metal tube handle with black bristles) in the appropriate oil to brush on parts being cut, drilled or tapped. The design uses a slot at the base of the inner tube to allow oil to get to the brush without sloshing. The holes on top allow dripped oil to flow back into the container.

Printer Brand:

FlashForge

Printer:

Creator Pro

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

Printed in ABS on glass with Wolfbite.

MUST BE PRINTED IN ABS TO USE ACETONE AS A GLUE AND SEALER. OTHER MATERIALS MAY WORK BUT THIS IS THE WAY I MADE MINE.

1. Once printed you must either brush an acetone/ABS slurry on the inside of the base and lid; or acetone smooth the parts, or brush or rinse the base and lid with acetone to seal the print against leakage. (You don't have to ask why I know this - first one in the trash)

  2. Check for fit of all parts before gluing.

  3. Using an ABS slurry with Acetone brush each mating part and assemble as follows:

  4. Glue the inner tube into the lid and align the 3 holes - The holes are equally spaced so there is no orientation - I used a nail in each hole to ensure alignment.

  5. Let dry.

NOTE: You can put a magnet inside to hold better to a steel surface and collect iron chips, but you can never clean the magnet once it is glued together.

  1. Glue the lid to the base - Again no orientation necessary, the slot in the inner tube can go in any direction. ( It is not necessary to glue the liner to the base, but you can if you wish)

  2. Let dry

  3. Add whatever oil you need: Steel cutting, Aluminum cutting, etc.

  4. Add a brush.

author: Cody_Rivas

description.text:
I created this mounting bracket to hold my RAMPS 1.4 controller.  I used cable ties to hold the Arduino to the mount and then used screws to hold the mount to a piece of 1/8" hardboard that was connected to the A-frame of my Prusa I2 with the included clips.  
Just one word of caution - don't cut the hardboard too wide or it might interfere with reaching your printers max height.  
I have included Parasolid files and SolidWorks 2014 part files.

I am in the process of building a custom MTG table for a friend who finally has space for it. I very much liked the D&D Logo corner decorations seen in this video (https://youtu.be/ghBB3jnHrhs?t=6m40s) however I do not have a CNC machine. I do have a 3D printer and the end result will come out pretty similar as long as we paint the table (instead of staining wood) - in fact they used 3D printed parts on the leg sculptures in this video.

So here are some corner piece options for this MTG table that you guys can use for whatever you like.

To design these I did a quick google search for MTG vectors and found a nice set here:
https://www.slightlymagic.net/forum/viewtopic.php?t=4430

Then I took the vectors for the mana symbols and the tap symbol in Adobe Illustrator and exported them as .DWG (autocad files)

Imported them into Sketchup (then had to fix some errors in them) and filled the outlines with faces. I did this by double clicking the outlines, then using the pencil tool and drawing over a single line segment of the outline. A little push/pull and a nice designer square to set it all on and we're golden. Then you just explode all the groups, merge the faces and delete any superfluous faces/edges.

Export them as .STL files and should be good to print.

For the MTG "M" logo and the tap symbol, I used the outer circle of the tap symbol and gave it a few mm of depth so it would actually print. For the "M" itself I simply found the appropriate font (Moria Citadel: http://www.dafont.com/moria-citadel.font) and used that for the M shape.

For the colorless/eldrazi style I just made that myself in sketchup (it's a simple shape) but I kept a circle around it to give it some visual appeal because it's so basic compared to the other mana symbols.

A holster to hold any kind of can that your heart desires. Cans fit like a glove. Great for a Saturday night with the boys. I went out last weekend with this bad boy and everybody asked me for one so now you can print it for yourselves.

title: Strong clip-on hook for wire shelves

description.text:
This is a larger, stronger version of my clip-on hook for standard wire shelves. I was able to hang a 35lb kettlebell from it (the only heavy thing nearby) without it breaking, as the photo shows. I do NOT actually recommend this for hanging things that heavy. My guess is that very heavy objects will eventually fatigue and break PLA (my current material), and drop said objects, possibly to the detriment of anything/person underneath.

The shelves these are designed for are very common in hardware stores, Sam's, office stores etc (see photos showing shelf). I deepened the snapping mechanism a bit from my other design, so these fit very snugly with a satisfying "snap." They are also removable.

The force from anything that hangs from them is primarily vertical, whereas horizontal force at one of the clips is needed for removal.

I use these to hang Acco clips that have papers and files attached to them; headsets; glasses; rolls of filament or baskets of small parts. They would be useful in a retail or showroom environment if you use this type of wire shelf. Experiment to see what you're comfortable hanging from them, and what they're useful for, and let me know :)

SolveSpace file is included.

author: joystick79

description.text:
A 3 axis gimbal I designed for a test fixture at work. The original had printed corners and machined sides due to our printer not being large enough to print all the sides. I did a test print of the bearing hole in ABS with a 0.4mm nozzle and standard Fine settings in Cura 2.6 on our Ultimaker 2 and the bearing was a nice press fit.

Stainless steel pins are used for the locking mechanisms. They were machined with grooves for 4 C-clips but I have listed external push rings which will work although you will only be able to install 3. Be sure to round off at least the one end of the pin so it will slide easily into the locking hole. Stick a block under the outer locking ring plate of sufficient height for the locking pins to clear the next ring by about an 1/8" and slide the inner locking ring up against the wall and seat in place with the external push rings. We reamed the locking pin holes to 0.128" and got a nice sliding fit which would stay back out of the way when in free swinging mode.

We used slip rings from Adafruit to get power and data into the center.

Assemble from the inside to outside (inside, middle, outer, outer #2). I used a washer on both sides of the joints for extra support. Use extra walls on the base so you can tap the 1/4-20 holes.

I updated the parts list as I missed a couple parts were not stainless steel.

EDIT 8/4/17: Added a D-Sub mount for a 15 pin D-sub connector. This is what I am using as part of the wiring system. You'll need longer screws where this mounts. I will post a picture soon of how I positioned them.

description.text:
Having never been happy with the ZMR 180 frame, as it is too high, and ungainly, I decided to go for a lowrider look. By removing the camera and vtx from the main body I was able to fit a Naze32, PDB, 4 esc's and the receiver in the enclosed part. making this a very tidy (but tight) build.

The camera part is supported by the original standoffs, but the body is now held together with m3 bolts.

The top of the camera housing has slots for velcro straps to hold a mobius or similar.

The first print in PLA proved a little fragile in high speed crashes, but with a few areas thickened and now printed, works well in ABS.

Initial flight testing on Cleanflight standard PID's appears OK, but much improved with tuning.

The usb access point is designed for a Naze32 rev6, above a standard PDB, Motors are DYS 1306 3100Kv, esc's 16a

The back of the camera section has small tubes to hold the antenna. There are two options for fpv cameras as my initial camera was an eachine 1000tvl, but I also wanted to use a smaller aio camera that I can keep the VTX available to easily change channel

When I can fly it and hold a camera at the same time I'll post a video.

title: Anet A8 improved linear chain clip
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I didn't really like the design of any of the existing clips, all the ones I tried kept falling out or just felt flimsy. It took me a while to get the right dimensions, but this one should fit perfectly. If it goes in too tight, do not force it, do not try to sand it or trim it, it's probably the chain link opening that needs cleanup. I printed 26 of these for my chain and only 3 wouldn't fit right because the chain links needed some light cleanup, but after that all fit well and are easy to remove when I need to replace hot end components

UPDATE: So you'll need 26 of these to have a clip in every hole except for the one on the motor bracket. For that one, just use some scotch tape, zip ties, or hot glue, it'll hold... {eye twitch} just kidding, I also attached an STL for the motor bracket clip. Yeah, if you're OCD like me having a zip tie on that last hole would cause you to lose sleep at night too. I mean come on, this is the place where people argue over using .15mm vs .2mm layer thickness and 195 vs 200 degrees, keep your glue guns in the drawer please. Enjoy

UPDATE 2: I just installed my an auto-level sensor, took less than 5 minutes to get all the clips off, run cable, put clips back. None broke, none lost their tightness. This design is definitely a keeper

UPDATE 3: Even without clips, my chain would snag on the filament every once in a while so I designed this remixed guide to prevent it. Highly recommend using one of these if you have a linear chain
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2562812

Anet A8

be sure they are laying down on their side when printing. you can make as many copies as you want by right clicking in cura and saying multiply by X. Also, make sure to use a skirt so that the nozzle is properly primed since this is such a small part it needs to start primed and ready to go

To install, the part with the pointed down rounded piece goes on top, the flat end goes in the square hole on your chain link. Again, do not force it in, if it does not slide in well clean up your chain link holes

description.text:
The extruder flat ribbon cable has a tendency to break near the connector at the extruder. This simple clip can be clipped onto the black extruder cover, and relieves the cable from strain near the connector. Hence it should prevent the cable from breaking.

You do not need to remove the black extruder cover, and need no screws. Just clip it on.

This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/kvbGNJRjmxA

comments.text: What a great, simple and effective design.  It does exactly what it supose to do, preventing mechanical deformation at the connector of the printing head.. TIP, secure the cable protector with a tie-wrap.

title: Flsun Cube 47mm Y Axis Replacement With Y Belt Tensioner

description.text:
This is a 'cutup' version of "Better Y axis for flsun cube" this time with 47mm linear rod spacing - which, from my measurements, is standard/original cube spacing. With 47mm spacing original X carriage can be reused. This is more an exercise in Fusion 360 for me as I use 70mm version therefore this is untested...but it should work.

Top of the X belt loop is made to be at the height of one of screws supporting X carriage's linear bearing holders. It needs to attach there from both sides of course. Because hotend is on front of the X carriage it probably would be best to put stepper Y carriage on the left side so belt is closer to center of the mass.

Please see notes on belt tensioning in the original.

comments.author: maly_japonec

comments.text:
It did not print very well. I spend a lot of time find material what can hold the nylon on the bed. I had one 100% working but it was 2mm thick and it bend itself with nylon. I though that it finally found it. Some gears I had to cut with steel plate and hammer but this time it started to release from the bed at height about 1cm. So the flat side is 1 mm bent. I do not know how it fits to the printer. The main reason I did it was belt tensioners. As the original method designed by the manufacturer I hate. But I started to think about making it from aluminium and partly from plastic. I have milling machine and lathe (mechanical only) so it is not problem to make some parts from it.
I will try to print it from ABS instead of nylon. Nylon is bending nightmare. I have heated box I can reach ambient temperatures over 70 (but the current printer - felix 3.1 could have problem with high temperatures so that is why i am making new printer for this heated box, where all electronics will be outside) but it makes no sense for nylon. It looked like the first layer was cold. The felix printer is peek extruder and so I do not go over 250 and it is cold for first layer it needs be very hot to get good stick with bed. Also reason why I am making new printer.
I am used to quality of the felix prints. It is quite precise as there are linear rails not bent rods like Flsun cube. Yes cube can be chaged to better, buying new precise rods, new bearings, new head carrier from metal and replacing all plastic parts... but it will be different printer.
As I need to return Felix next month I need to start print and improvement later.
This print was just for test If I can do it from nylon. I can but it does not look good and shape is not perfect.
comments.author: MichaelLamb

comments.text: Finally I decided to not use that prints. I will keep original design but I will make the plates from 5mm aluminium and I bought bearings that are able to fix by screws. No more plastic holders and cable ties. Bar holders will be replace with metal ones. And at the end probably bars will be replaced with precisely ground with 8mm size not 7.93 as was almost all I received in package.

Clip-in are designed to go in, not out, so they may need to be slid out the end or broken to remove. Once a screw goes in, the part will lock into place, so it could also act as a stop.
Printing flat part up/dn makes it resist the leg breaking.

title: Lizard95 Video Transmitter Deck and Run Cam Micro Mount

description.text:
This video transmitter mount was designed because the included combination video camera / video transmitter on the Eachine Lizard 95 is so poor. Almost everyone who buys this quad copter has had the wires separate and the camera fail and it is very hard to fix. The camera is also very poor with shadow detail even when working. This modification gives you a nice location to mount a separate video transmitter. It was designed to fit the cheap Eachine VTx03 transmitter and weighs in at approximately 1.1 gram. The slot in the back is for a wire tie to be added so you can heat shrink the antenna to the wire tie. This version is for people who will be using a 15mm wide or less separate video camera. The only frame modification necessary is to grind off the decorative teeth on the back of the side frames. The front tabs are designed to snap into the small slot on the frame but may need some slight sanding as the fit is tight. Feedback / comments are welcome.

I will be releasing another version with a modified front connection system when I finish the design for the Run cam swift mounting brackets since the Run Cam swift requires a 20 mm spacing and can not fit inside the current frames.

I just posted the modified VTx mount to use with the camera.  I just flew everything tonight for the first time and it is amazing. comments.author: DrNoxious

comments.text:
They are not screws they are fine thread bolts. They fit perfectly as I am using all (4) on my setup with no special preparation or drilling needed. Simply pre-screw them into the holes to properly thread the plastic before trying to mount. Again if you print quality is not right on your printer, then you may have tolerance issues. A number of other tips can be found here https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showpost.php?p=38082756&postcount=1850
and here https://www.rcgroups.com/forums/showpost.php?p=38126584&postcount=1998

title: Anet A8 J-Head compatible mount (supports E3D v5/v6 etc) UPDATED

description.text:
DISCLAIMER: I haven't actually attached this to my printer as I'm waiting for some fittings for the rest of the bowden setup, however there's nothing that I see that could be an issue.

I've installed it into my printer and realised that it triggers the end stop 12.5mm before it should so I would use the G28 (to home) and then M206 command to see what your current offsets are if there are any say your offset is X-40 Y-20 Z0 Then I would change it to X-24

My settings are X-14 Y-20 Z0.

I printed my design in simplify 3d however I imagine other slicers would work too, supports will be needed for the main bracket and also the front of the clamp, the goal of this design was to make a j-head mount that was as light as possible and for it to support the popular

"Spriya" - High Efficiency Anet A8 Fan Duct" found here:

https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2133328

I just used the method that original metal mount used for attaching the belts to the carriage which is using a screw and a nut, you can use the ones that came with the printer to achieve this.

To attach the fan I'm going to be using some left over parts that I had from the printer, namely the M3x30 screws for attaching the part cooling fan, you'll probably need to print off a spacer if you're using nyloc nuts like I am however it's not required. It's just a measure to make the nyloc nuts last a tiny bit longer.

As far as I'm aware the print head is the exact same place as the bone stock version so you won't need to make any alterations in the firmware for extruder offsets. However I may redesign this with option of having two j heads on one carriage, in that case there will need to be an offset.

If you have any questions, or possible improvements for this design leave them in the comments.

Try and follow the same supports as I've done in simplify3d however, supports are not needed for the Knurled Screw.

https://www.facebook.com/oliver.jackson.376/videos/10212030623494821/

If you need a E3D V5 clone fusion file like the one I used to design your own x-carriage then you can find that here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2456199

I noticed that the screw that I originally uploaded had a 3mm across flats head so I changed it and uploaded two, one that's 2.55mm that I imagine will work with most printers (2.4mm being the head size I was aiming for) and 2.45 if you're feeling adventurous.

I've updated it to have a more substantial fan holder as the previous one was quite prone to wiggling, I've also accomodated for the endstop position so you no longer get prints that are offset.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30%

title: Power Supply Fan Mount 80mm - Anet A8
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 80mm Fan Mount for the Anet A8 Power Supply (base 50mm x 110mm), to prevent it from burning.
If you want to have any modification, like a cablemanagement, or other fan sizes you can do it by yourself (.stp and .scad included), or just leave a comment, i'll see what i can do.

What you need

  • 4x M3x18 or M3x20
  • 4x M3 nut
  • 1x M3x6 or M3x8 (optional to screw it down to the power supply, but it also sits strong
    without a screw)

PS: The screw-hole on the back has been set to the correct position (Not how it is in my picture).

Changelog:
I added a version with a round fan hole. That can be printed witout any support (thanks to https://www.thingiverse.com/LordCarvalho for profing it).

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0,2mm

Infill:

0%-100%

Notes:

All Walls in this part have a thickness of 1.6mm, so i would print it with this wall size, bottom- and top-layer thickness. Than you won't need to care about infill. The support should be round about 8% and must be everywhere, not only touching buildplate!
Printingtime on my A8 with 50mm/s and 0,2mm layer heigh 05:57.

The "Power Supply Fan Mount Anet A8 - round" could be printed without support (not tested).
The position of the screw-hole on the back has been corrected.

title: Qidi Tech X-One LED strip vertical (re)mount

description.text:
This clip is designed to hold on to the right front edge of the face of the Qidi Tech X-one and allows for the LED strip to be relocated vertically.The slight lip is an attempt to prevent light from coming out the front.

NOTE: Print 6 of these for full height coverage - I limited the height to make it modular and more stable when printing.

To remove the lights from their stock downward facing position, remove the 4 screws holding 2 small plastic retention clips in place then slowly peel the LED strip off of the inside. There should be enough adhesive left to re-adhere to the clips once positioned, but glue could also be used.

I've been experimenting with multi-lithopane pictures recently, and this framed, six-part doge that I made for my roommate's birthday is the first one that worked out.  
I used the large doge source image on Know Your Meme and cut it into six square sections. The picture sections were then processed through Customizable Lithopane and the frame was modelled in 123D Design.

The frame has been pre-cut to fit on my Afinia H479 build platform, but the original STL file is also there.  
If you're feeling adventurous, deepening the groove in the frame would make the project assemble a little more easily.  
The lithopane sections are 12 layers at 0.20 mm, in the large square format with no hole. (The picture sections are included if you want to re-process them.)  
Other than that, you basically just have to print everything out and glue it all together.

A wall mount for an iPhone 4 in a folding case. There is room left both in the front and back sides of the phone so the front can be folded behind the phone while it's charging.

The 30pin plug lives in a hole beneath the phone that holds the plug inside the dock when not in use. When mounted, the plug still fits in the hole beneath the phone so the phone is not standing on the plug as in some other docks -- you pull the plug up from the dock to it insert into the phone manually, before mounting the phone in the dock. This means that you are able to pull the phone out of the dock without disconnecting the plug for that casual look at an app while charging.

title: Garden Valve 0.1
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
THIS IS A WORK IN PROGRESS! It leaks a lot unless fully-open or fully-closed.

The plug valve and the ball valve designs seem the most solid and 3d printable. This first try is the ball valve.

Required vitamins:

  • 2 x hose washer
  • 4 x 25mm M3 strengthening bolts
  • 4 X M3 nuts
  • 1 x 6mm airsoft BB (as axle)
  • 1/4" hex bit to turn it

It is highly recommended to acetone-polish the part for 20min after printing it.

How it works: The center ball is held tightly between two hose washers, which do all the sealing work.

I'm not sure the nuts/bolts are entirely necessary, it could have just been the acetone polishing which made it stronger, but this is the first one that didn't blow apart so I'm not going to question it.

comments.text: Typically those valves have a flat ledge where the handle goes on, they put a gasket between the body and the handle to seal it. (and the handle is held on via a screw into the ball.
comments.author: rue_mohr

comments.text: Thank you.  i'm trying to stick with vitamins people can easily and cheaply get.  Next I may try a plug valve, I can size that to use the same size gasket (hose gasket) for all things.

NOTE: NOT FULLY TESTED YET - YMMV A Bowden extruder design for use with the One-Up/Two-Up printer models from QU-BD. Supports the Ubis-style hot-end that ships with those printer kits as well as "Groove-mount" style hot-ends such as E3D and Pico. Designed to work with my mechanical endstop bracket set (the left edge of the extruder has a bumper for tapping the X endstop). Has a mounting shelf and ventilation duct for a high-airflow "blower" fan as well as a mounting point for Z-Probe servo. Requires additional hardware:
  • various M3 bolts
  • various M2 bolts
  • various M3 hex nuts
  • various M2 hex nuts
    • Optional cooling hardware:
  • 30mm x 30mm blower fan for Ubis intake cooling
  • 40mm x 40mm blower fan for nozzle cooling
    • 40mm fan: http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?mpart=BFB0412HHA-A&vendor=603
    30mm fan: http://www.digikey.com/product-search/en?mpart=BFB0312HA-A&vendor=603 Optional hardware for bed autoleveling (requires additional electronics due to printrboard limitations):
  • Standard Micro Servo
  • Normally-Open lever switch
    • Updated: changed Ubis mounting clamp to support an always-on blower fan that keeps the intake of the barrel cool Also removed the cold-end mount since it didn't fit very well.

title: Scalable retraction, overhang and layer bonding (watertight) calibration test

description.text: Good day, this calibration test is a real torture test for any printer when it comes to no room for error., this print tests the retraction, overhang and layer bonding all in one; looks can be deceiving especially with such a simple design. Their is only 1mm layer at the bottom and it is part of a hollow cone inside of a hollow circle fused with a hollow cylinder. the bottom layer is hollow and must remain that way.after filling the top hole with water. Take a look at GOOD DAY.txt for more info and make sure to scale it as you may need it.

Printer:

tevo tarantula

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

100-300 micron (.25 - .4 mm nozzle recommended)

Infill:

100% rectilinear (a must)

Notes:

Take a look for GOOD DAY.txt for more info on how to print. My personal experience with filament has lead me to believe filament properties may have something to do with layer bonding issues and simple things such as a small draft of air or a speck of dust may also affect the final print. The intention with this calibration test was to figure out why many rolls of filament were being discarded while trying to print watertight designs, the answer was not a a simple word or number and proved that even the slightest of error in any area made this task impossible. The design as is will most likely succeed without error but that is no fun, PLEASE take a look at GOOD DAY.txt for more info (I can't stress this part enough!). Good day and Good luck. 

p.s. It is absolutely possible to print large water tight prints with zero leaks.

Thought I'd upload a template that I made for a ps4 controller lightbar, just edit the lightbar with whatever image or text to make it your own! :)

If you would like to have your own designed by me, just comment what you want or send me a private message.

This is just a simple 3D representation of the UTSA (University of Texas at San Antonio) mascot Rowdy extracted from a 2D print.

I print with extruder temp set to 200 C, and a heated bed set to 55 C. If you don't have a heated bed you may want to add a brim to keep sharp edges from curling.
